perturbation.original_text:
9.9 Applicable Law 
This IP Agreement and the legal relations among the Parties will be governed by and construed in accordance with the rules and substantive Laws of the State of California, United States of America, without regard to conflicts of law provisions.
perturbation.changed_text:
9.9 Applicable Law 
This IP Agreement and the legal relations among the Parties will be governed by and construed in accordance with the rules and substantive laws as determined solely by Sony Electronics Inc., without regard to conflicts of law provisions.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the explicit reference to California law, giving SONY unilateral power to determine the applicable law. This introduces a legal risk because it could be interpreted as an attempt to circumvent consumer protection laws or other regulations mandated by California.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Legal Remedies Act, California Civil Code Section 1750 et seq.

perturbation.original_text:
9.14 Attorneys' Fees 
If any action at law or in equity is necessary to enforce or interpret the terms of this IP Agreement, the Person prevailing shall be entitled to recover in such action its reasonable attorneys' fees, costs and necessary disbursements in addition to any other relief to which it may be entitled.
perturbation.changed_text:
9.14 Attorneys' Fees 
If any action at law or in equity is necessary to enforce or interpret the terms of this IP Agreement, Sony Electronics Inc. may be entitled to recover attorneysâ€™ fees at the sole discretion of Sony Electronics Inc.
perturbation.explanation: The original text grants attorneys' fees to the prevailing party. The modified text gives SONY sole discretion in determining if and when it can recover these fees, effectively removing the reciprocal right of GSI Technology to claim attorneys' fees if they prevail. This puts GSI at a legal disadvantage, especially if Sony chooses not to award fees even when GSI is successful in court. It violates the legal tenet of even playing field.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Code of Civil Procedure Section 1021 et seq.

perturbation.original_text:
9.3 Successors and Assigns 
This IP Agreement will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Parties hereto and their respective successors and permitted assigns, but will not be assignable or delegable by any Party without the prior written consent of the other Party. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Party may transfer or assign its rights under this IP Agreement in connection with a merger, acquisition or sale of all or substantially all of its assets, on condition that it provides the other Party with notice of the transfer or assignment. Any attempted transfer in contravention of this Section 9.3 shall be null and void.
perturbation.changed_text:
9.3 Successors and Assigns 
This IP Agreement will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Parties hereto and their respective successors and permitted assigns, but will not be assignable or delegable by GSI Technology without the prior written consent of Sony Electronics Inc. Any attempted transfer in contravention of this Section 9.3 shall be null and void.
perturbation.explanation: This change restricts GSI Technology's ability to assign the agreement while leaving Sony's rights unrestricted. Many jurisdictions have laws ensuring reasonable freedom to assign contracts, especially in cases like mergers or acquisitions. This asymmetry creates a legal risk as it may be deemed unconscionable or an unfair business practice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600
